chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Therefore, a conversion that upholds the correctness of faith and the rule of a good life is pleasing and acceptable in the sight of God. This means that, first and foremost, a correct understanding of God should be maintained, and then the love commanded by God should be shown to one's neighbor. A person loves themselves correctly when they, being devout and humble, prioritize the love of God. They also love their neighbor if they help them reach God with correct faith and good conduct, as much as they can.

The love for one's neighbor must be maintained in two ways: first, by not inflicting anything on others that one would not want inflicted on oneself; and second, by not denying help to the needy as much as one can, because one would not want to be denied help if they were similarly in need. Hence, we recognize that our Savior informs us with the words: "Whatever you want people to do to you, do also to them. This is the law and the prophets" Matthew 7:12. Christ did not say, "Whatever people have done to you, do also to them," so that we would not think it right to repay evil for evil to someone who has wronged us, or to withhold a benefit from someone because they have not benefited us. A Christian ought to offer or return assistance of goodwill to everyone; to return good for good, and to overcome evil with goodness.

For the Lord tells us: "Love your enemies, do good to those who hate you, and pray for those who persecute and slander you, so that you may be children of your Father in heaven, who makes his sun rise on the good and the evil, and sends rain on the just and the unjust" Matthew 5:44-45. Good and faithful people suffer persecution not only from those outsiders who oppose the doctrines of the Catholic Church with faithless and perverse barking; but also from those who seem to be within the Church, but are found to live wickedly and oppose ecclesiastical tradition not in words, but in deeds.
chunks.original_latin:
Conversio ergo illa in conspectu Dei grata est et
accepta, in qua simul et fidei rectitudo servatur, et
vitae bonae regula custoditur: id est, ut principaliter
recta teneatur de Deo sententia, deinde proximo exhibeatur
 caritas divinitus imperata. Tunc enim se
homo recte diligit, cum dilectionem Dei sibi devotus
et humilis anteponit. Tunc etiam diligit proximum,
si proximo, quantum potest, consulat, ut ad Deum
recta fide et bona conversatione perveniat. Proximi
autem caritas duplici est ratione servanda, ut scilicet
nec alii inferat quidquam quod sibi nollet inferri;
nec indigenti opem boni operis in quantum potest
deneget, quia nec sibi vellet negari, si similiter indigeret. Unde Salvatoris nostri sic nos agnoscimus informari
 sermone dicentis: Quae vultis ut faciant vobis
homines, eadem et vos facite eis. Haec est enim lex et
prophetae (Matth VII 12). Non dixit Christus, quae
vobis fecerint homines, eadem et vos facite eis; ne
malum crederemus pro malo reddendum ei qui nobis
mali aliquid fecit, aut cuiquam negandum putaremus
beneficium, a quo nobis nihil beneficii sciremus impensum:
cum debeat Christianus omni homini benevolentiae
adjutorium, vel praerogare, vel reddere;
ut et bono bonum reddat, et malum bonitate praeveniat. Dicitur enim nobis a Domino: Diligite inimicos
vestros, benefacite his qui vos oderunt, et orate pro
persequentibus et calumniantibus vos, ut sitis filii patris
vestri qui in coelis est, qui solem suum facit oriri
super bonos et malos, et pluit super justos et injustos
(Matth V 44 45). Boni autem fideles, non solum
 ab illis persecutionem patiuntur qui foris positi latratibus
perfidis ac perversis Ecclesiae catholicae dogmatibus
obnituntur; sed etiam ab illis qui videntur
quidem intra Ecclesiam esse, sed male viventes inveniuntur
ecclesiasticae traditioni non ore, sed opere
repugnare.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
<speak>
    
        When good people see them, they groan deeply. The good heart, moved by holy affection, is tormented because it cannot avoid being aware of others' perversity, even though it cannot agree with it.
    
</speak>
chunks.original_latin:
Quos cum boni conspiciunt, graviter gemunt,
et sancto affectu permotus cruciatur bonus
animus, quando alienae perversitatis non fugit sensum,
quamvis tenere non possit assensum.
